key_risks: Legal and ethical concerns, including a $36 million jury verdict in a disability discrimination case
Regulatory and compliance risks, including safety, environmental, and labor laws
Operational challenges such as driver shortages and fuel price volatility
controversies: Significant legal setback with a $36 million jury verdict in a disability discrimination case
environmental_issues: Commitment to reducing CO2 emissions and improving fuel efficiency
social_issues: Driver workforce is 55% ethnically diverse, but potential risks related to workplace practices and compliance with anti-discrimination laws
Industry-wide shortage of qualified truck drivers
governance_issues: Potential risks related to workplace practices and compliance with anti-discrimination laws
Focus on cybersecurity and data privacy compliance

sources.title: Jury Awards Over $36 Million in EEOC Disability Discrimination Case ...
sources.snippet: ST. LOUIS - An eight-person jury in Omaha, Nebraska returned a verdict of $36,075,000 in favor of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) on disability discrimination claims against Drivers Management, LLC and Werner Enterprises, Inc., the federal agency announced today.

sources.title: Texas Supreme Court Weighs $116M Trucking Crash Verdict
sources.snippet: Werner Enterprises Inc. is challenging a $116 million jury verdict that found the company and one of its drivers liable for a deadly crash in icy conditions. The case arose after a truck driven by Zaragoza "Trey" Salinas lost control on Interstate 20, crossed the median, and collided with another truck driven by Werner driver Shiraz Ali.
